1 minute: Objectives

Understand the importance of having a strong professional brand.
Define how you create value for others in your life.
Create a LinkedIn account and begin to build your network.

2

WHO DO YOU WANT TO BE?
What are your values and mission?
What value can you create?
What are you trying to achieve in life?


15 minutes: Lecture + activity

When we talk about personal branding, it covers many of the same things as branding for your business. All of you know yourselves and have a vision for the future. You all add value and create something special in this world. While creating your personal brand, your job is to share your mission and communicate that value with others. Personal branding allows you to show what matters to YOU. As founders, your personal brand should be somewhat tied into your business brand. For example, maybe you personally care so much about the environment and you are on a mission to make the world a safer and more healthy place for people. You can work towards accomplishing that mission in so many ways (start a business that has a positive impact on the environment, start a blog tackling environmental issues, buy eco-friendly products, etc….) 
So before we get into ways that you can get yourself out there and start building a strong personal brand, you need to take some time to understand who you are and what you stand for. 

Activity: 15 Minutes
10 minutes: Individual work
Ask the entrepreneurs to take out a pen and paper and answer the following questions:
What value can you create?
What are your values and mission? 
What are you trying to achieve in life?
5 minutes: Share
Go around the room and have a few people share their answers

Recap: The first step to crafting your personal brand is to lay a foundation that you can confidently and authentically build upon. The key principle here is authenticity. There is a misconception that building a personal brand means crafting a persona. But a persona, by definition, is a facade. It’s not a true reflection of who you are, and therefore, it’s inauthentic. Your personal brand should not be an inauthentic persona. You are the face of your business and you need to show up loud and proud about all of the amazing things that you are doing. 

3

YOUR PERSONAL BRAND
10-15 minutes: Discussion

Ask: What are ways that you can begin building this brand now? What can you do to get your name (and your business) out there? 
Potential answers:
Create a LinkedIn
Participate in events, panel discussions, and pitch competitions to build a better network and let other people know you and what you are trying to accomplish
Getting featured in the media, having a personal brand makes it easier for you to pitch and be found by the media (online publications, magazines, television, radio, podcasts, social media posts, articles, post by influencers, etc.). The media is in constant search of experts that can share their insights with their audience.
Create valuable content, and share it with others. Portray yourself as an expert in something. Create something valuable that others will want to share. As they share your brand, they also will be sharing your business that you represent. 
Start to introduce yourself to more people, follow up with them, and get in contact with each other to find ways to mutually support each other (begin networking!)
Brand recognition is one of the biggest obstacles for startups, and many never achieve it. Online marketing campaigns may not work if you do not make the effort to spread the word and show the world what you are capable of. To increase visibility. If you want to build a famous brand, there is often a person pushing that behind the scenes. You want to build awareness and show what you are doing  (which is running your business).

Ask: Why is it important that you actually work to implement these things and develop this brand? Who is involved and how does that impact your business?
Contacts: Having good contacts in today’s business world is so important. 
Partners: Having a strong professional brand shows that you are professional and have passion to be able to run your business. Show others that you are an expert in your field and that you are the right person to be running your business. This is a must have when approaching partners and potential collaborators. 
Customers: You may also find new customers for your business. With so many small businesses popping up, a brand that connects to a customer is much easier to trust faster. People will trust your business more if they know who is running it. It builds trust to see a face of someone doing good things behind the scenes and see all the experience they have. 
Investors: The best way to gain the attention of an investor is by speaking to him/her directly. Face to face conversations build trust and are the foundation of a future relationship. People can only invest in your business when they know you exist, and see that you are professional. 
You need to convince people around you that you are professional, and you have the grit, passion, and ethics to lead a business. People look at the individual's capability of carrying out a business idea. Increase the chance of investment. 
Good ideas are a dime a dozen. If the person isn’t there to implement the project and lead the organization, the good idea will fail. Investors tend to invest in the founders ability to bring an idea to life. Not the idea.
Team: When the founders stand for something and build a strong brand identity around a mission, this will trickle down to the business itself. Based on your values, you will create your policies and company culture. A strong founder is a part of a strong team which will make an even stronger company.

Recap: Your personal brand will be defined by your actions and how people view those actions. If you DON'T want to work to build a personal brand, you should realize that everything you do reflects on your business. If your reputation is as a cheat and liar, then it's going to be a poor reflection on your business. There is so much you can be doing right now to start developing a positive brand image and deliver your message to the world. Over the next few slides, we will talk about some of these ideas in more detail and brainstorm ways to actually implement them.

4

NETWORK
5-10 minutes: Discussion

One great way to get yourself out there is through networking. Face to face networking is all about exchanging ideas and information with the people you meet in order to create relationships that could help you grow your business. Already, you have had so many opportunities to network with people. Whether it is the judges that come for competitions, CEO Talks, business breakfasts, or people in the co-working space, Five One Labs holds events all the time, and you should take advantage of it! Make sure that you are taking the opportunity to talk to them and start that long-term relationship. 

If it was not mentioned on the previous slide, ask: How might your network be able to help you or your business?
Potential answers:
Find new customers, 
Find partners, 
Find suppliers
Provide information, advice or mentorship
Provide technical support,
Help find investment or other needed resources
Find team members or co-founders
Etc…

Ask: When you meet people face to face, what are some best practices? Note: Keep in mind that a lot of this is cultural and you should be able to recognize that one style doesn’t fit every situation. Be aware of who you are talking too so that you don’t come off too cocky and turn people off.
Potential answers:
Use stories to evoke emotions. You want to listen to them as well. Learn about what they are doing to try to find ways to collaborate in the future. Being a good listener is one of the best ways to be a good communicator.
Show actual evidence of what you are doing. Show them your website or product if it is available.
Smile when you speak. Look engaged and happy to be there.
Be memorable especially when you are meeting high profile people
Create a link between the two of you.
Have good body language.
Be confident! Even though it can be uncomfortable to talk to new people, just pretend you are confident for the time being. Confidence is key!
Be empathetic about the other person and their work .
Be open minded. You never know who you will meet and how they might be able to help you. 
Ask for their business card or a way to reach out again
Set up a reason why you might reach out again in the near future
Always be respectful
Ask: Networking can be hard and really intimidating especially for shy people. What are some best practices for networking when you are more introverted? 
Potential answers:
Network in groups
Look for other people standing alone. They might be a bit shy as well and easy to talk to
See if you can find out who is at the event ahead of time so you can mentally prepare yourself
Do your best to put yourself out there. Try not to stand in the corner alone by the snacks! Or you can use that as a really easy starting point for conversations.
Commit yourself to a goal before the event. 
Speak to 5 people 
Get 5 business cards. 
Find 1 person who could be a customer in the future
Etc… 
5

HOLD AND ATTEND EVENTS
5 minutes: Discussion

A great way to get your name out there is by holding events. 
Ask: Why is holding events so important to do (especially as an early stage startup)?  What kind of events can you start to hold right now?
Potential answers:
Get your name out there
Make partnerships and connections with different players in the ecosystem
Find potential customers
Find employees
You can have product testing events
You can have a launch party
You can have an event related to your mission and invite other organizations and people interested in your mission

Share an example of how holding events is really important.
The picture above shows the founder of Fix-It (an application that connects repair men to people who need something repaired in their home) meeting with a group of repair men. In this meeting, she gave an overview of the application and how it worked. She allowed them to test her product and give feedback on it. She was able to use this as an opportunity to sign repair men onto her platform which was essential for her product to work.

If you don’t hold your own events, you can at least attend events. If you want to network, go to as many events as you can. The more you talk to people about your mission and business, the more people will know about it. You can’t spend all your time at events, so be strategic about what you attend. It is a great idea to go to events that will have the people you are looking to meet. 
Ask: If you are interested in meeting potential customers, where might you go? 
Answer: Go to events/places where customers will be such as public events, universities, etc… (you have to know your customers to answer this)
Ask: If you are interested in meeting people who could partner or invest in your business, where might you go? 
Answer: Go to events/places where they are such as business seminars and workshops.
6

GET FEATURED IN MEDIA
5 minutes: Lecture + discussion

Getting featured in the media is a great way to build a strong reputation. These media outlets usually have a strong following and will give you a lot of visibility.
Give 1-2 examples of entrepreneurs who have been successful at this: 
Randi from our FFF was highlighted on Babylon FM. Randi is the founder of Shopyobrand. She is really active and tries to get visibility for her business.
Laylan from Dada was highlighted on NRT. From this press (among other things she was doing publically), she was able to build a buzz around her business. She even got invited to Baghdad to pitch and came in 3rd place. She made it to the next level and was able to go to Lebanon where she pitched again.

Ask: How could you get yourself featured in the media? 
Potential answers:
Network with people! The more you talk to people and put yourself out there, the more of a chance there will be of someone who might be in the industry or know someone who can help you get featured somewhere. 
At Five One Labs, we have journalists and reporters come for all different reasons (Demo Day, events, sometimes they just ask to do a story). If we see that you are active with your business and are making great progress, we will suggest your name to them. Alternatively, don’t be afraid to just approach these people and talk to them. They might offer to include you in a piece, but sometimes you might have to have to ask. 
If you are active and in the spotlight, people might reach out to you to learn more about what you are doing. 
Media outlets usually want to tell a good story so inspire others with your mission and vision.
Etc…
7

WORK WITH INFLUENCERS
5 minutes: Discussion

Influencers are usually trusted in the market because they are popular or have great knowledge and experience in a particular field. People really trust them and they have the ability to influence the purchasing of their audience. Even if they don’t influence purchases, they can influence their followers to also follow you or to spread the word about what you are doing. 
Ask: If you wanted to work with an influencer, how would you approach this?
Potential answers:
You can DM them
Use someone in your network to connect you
You can reach out to super famous people (you probably won’t get an answer), or you can reach out to smaller less known influencers
Etc…

In general, you can follow these 5 steps to find influencers to work with on social media: 
Monitor conversations online to see who is popular in the space
Identify influential people who you might be able to work with
Pinpoint what factors/values you share with these influencers so that you can approach them in a good way
Locate and recruit the influencers to work with you or partner on a project/campaign
Incentivize them to work with you. Sometimes you have to pay really popular influencers, but not always. If you are smart about who you approach and how you do it, you might be able to do this for free and benefit from sharing each other’s followers. You usually have to have a clearly aligned and mutually beneficial mission for this to work well. 

Ask: Who are people that you already know that you could potentially work with? Who are well known and influential people who are working towards a similar mission?
Maybe people have answers to this already, but maybe they don’t
Suggest that they begin to look into this and create a list of some people to partner with in this way. 
8

CREATE A LINKEDIN
1 hour and 10 minutes: Discussion + activity

5-10 minutes: Discussion
Finally, the last thing we will talk about as a way to build your personal brand is LinkedIn.
Ask: Who here has a LinkedIn? What do you use it for? How can you use LinkedIn to share your message and build your network?
Potential answers:
People who have (or have had) LinkedIn profiles should share. 
LinkedIn is a social media platform for professionals. 
It is a great platform to get visibility and put your face on the map.
You can use it to share skills, knowledge, resources, ideas, and more.
You can search for a job or post job offerings here.
It is a platform to tell your story or the story of your business.
You can have a business profile to create more brand awareness.
You are on a platform full of people who are interested in business, making partnerships, and more. 
You can find founders, students, employees, investors, subject matter experts, and more all in one place.
Conversation topics can be about a variety of industries, sectors, and locations.
You can learn about other businesses and opportunities.
Find supporters, advisors, or mentors.
You can stay up to date on trends and news in your industry.
It is a great platform for creating and building your network. You can add people that you meet from other networking events to your Linked in to help stay in touch. You can also use your LinkedIn to grow your network by posting content, engaging in conversations, and more. 
Potential partners and collaborators are there. If you are looking to make a connection to a particular business or looking for someone with a particular skill, you can easily search and find people on LinkedIn. If you have mutual friends, sometimes you can request an introduction to someone in the organization.  For instance, I have a project that I think UNHCR would be a great partner for, but I don’t know anyone from the organization, I can ask my friend who works there to connect me with one of her connections. Keep in mind that not everyone is willing to put out their connections for you, you have to prove to be highly professional, otherwise it would look bad for your friend (and the brand they are building for themselves). 
Attract more clients by participating in events and sharing your experience with your network, building a personal brand that positions you as the go-to expert in a specific industry or niche helps you to attract more of your ideal clients. When you’re positioned as an expert, it’s also easier for people to refer clients to you.

Ask: What does Ameen’s LinkedIn profile say about him?
You can see from his picture that he is professional, but possibly fun and approachable. He looks very friendly.
He is showcasing his business Pharx and the value that it creates “Affordable Medicine in your Hands” in a very simple and clear way.
“Entrepreneur in Residence” is showing that he is an entrepreneur and lives in Mosul
His “About” section shows that he is a founder. It talks about his passion for entrepreneurship and innovation. His passion is directly tied into his business.

1 hour: Activity
Entrepreneurs will now work on their LinkedIn (either starting from scratch or updating their current profile)
Use the Personal Branding Checklist handout to guide you on what to do. 
A trainer will go around helping entrepreneurs get the right wording of their headlines and about me section. Make sure that it highlights their passion and it is also tied into their business. 
As entrepreneurs build their LinkedIn page, make sure they highlight the following points: 
Create your profile: Sign up and create your profile.
Make good connections: You can begin by adding your family, friends, past or current classmates, coworkers, judges, visitors from CEO Talks and other events to your network. 
Highlight experience and expertise: Your professional bio is an important piece of personal information that will help you catch the interest of the viewer. It can be awkward writing about yourself, but it is important to highlight your past experience and successes. What skills have you acquired throughout your life? What training, credentials, certifications, or awards have you received? It is ok if your background doesn’t tie in perfectly with your business, but try to find links and similarities wherever you can (remember that a brand is consistent and telling a good story). 
Highlight your personality: What are some of your most important core values? What do you believe in? What do you stand for? What do you stand against? What industries and topics are you most interested in? What are you passionate about?

Trainer note: On a rare occasion, an entrepreneur might not want to do this. Encourage that they create one, but don’t force them. The entrepreneur can use the time to help other people in the cohort with this activity or work individually to come up with a personal branding plan. 
9

FOLLOW UP
3 minutes: Discussion

Ask: After you begin meeting new people and growing your network face to face, what should you do?
Potential answers: 
Follow up! 
Reach out over email, phone, social media, or LinkedIn (depending on how your initial meeting went you might want to be more or less professional). 
Some people might say to ask for something (which is fine), but make sure that they know when it is an appropriate time to ask for things (this point will be covered on slide 13).
10

ENGAGE MEANINGFULLY
5 minutes: Discussion

The follow up element of this is really important. You will never meet someone and then instantly they will provide you with all you need. You need to follow up with them and build a relationship with them over time. It would be good to learn about their needs so that you can help them too. 

Ask: What are ways that you can engage with the people you have met? How can you continue the conversation and build relationships?
Potential answers:
Email them to follow up on your conversation from when you met. Maybe give them resources based on what you talked about. Did they offer to provide you with something? If so, remind them. – During the follow up, make sure that you are polite and not demanding. Send an email and a follow up, but if there is no answer, back off and give the person some space. You shouldn’t assume that anything is guaranteed. 
Distinguish how professional the contact is. If they are more friendly, consider reaching out over Whatsapp or text message
Follow up on LinkedIn:
Post content: Post about the event you were at where you met the person. 
Tag people. This will encourage the people who were tagged to like, comment, and share which will help spread awareness about you and your business. 
Use the right hashtags to help you show up in the right conversations
Share pictures
Let people know what you are up to!

Participate in conversations: You can also contribute your knowledge and skills in conversations that are happening on the platform. You can easily participate in conversations on LinkedIn. Participating in conversations can allow you to share your perspective on relevant issues, things happening in your industry, and topics with others. You can like and comment on posts and articles on LinkedIn. You can create or join groups to connect and grow with members who share your interests, experiences, or aspirations.
11

ASK!
5 minutes: Discussion

Don’t forget, as you build your network, you are building opportunities for collaboration. You should feel comfortable reaching out to people in your network when you need something. Benefit from the relations you made and start asking and growing.  

Ask: What can you use your network for? How might they be able to help you?
Potential answers:
Provide expertise or mentorship
Support in a variety of areas or make a connection to someone else who can. Areas might include:
Customers
Partners
Supplier
Mentor
Investor
Etc…

Ask: Although a lot of this changes culture to culture, what are things you should do and not do when reaching out to your network for something?
Do:
Build a relationship with the person first. Spend time with them and learn about their needs.
Be polite
Offer something in return (time, support, resources, money, etc…)
Find things you have in common or common things that you are working on 
In emails, write a meaningful subject line and keep the message focused. 
Identify yourself clearly and remind the person of how you met and what you talked about.
Asking for advice is a good first step to start a conversation.
Proofread.

Don’t:
Don’t be too direct. Don’t just randomly email someone you are not close to and ask for something
Don’t expect them to just say “yes”. Be aware of the fact that the person might not be interested
Don’t be rude or too demanding
Don’t ask things from strangers
Don’t be too formal/informal. Distinguish between formal and informal situations and know when it is appropriate/inappropriate to ask for things. 

Recap: Once you build a relationship of mutual trust, then you can benefit from the relationship by asking for something. This can be anything from sharing their network, to advice, to resources. Be careful with your ask. Always be respectful and don’t demand anything.

12

BUILD YOUR BUSINESS
Define how you will develop your personal brand and work towards achieving your personal mission.

Create your LinkedIn and apply the personal branding checklist to your profile.

Start taking professional photos!

5 minutes: Wrap up

Connecting sustainability progress with networks and entrepreneurs

Below is an **example of how you might integrate sustainability networks and entrepreneurs into the existing “Personal Brand + Networking” slides** using a **before/after** approach. It shows **what changes** you’re making and **why**, while keeping your slides concise. You can, of course, adapt the suggested networks and individuals to what’s most relevant in your region.

---

## 1. **Slide: NETWORK (Before/After)**

### **BEFORE** 
```
NETWORK
5-10 minutes: Discussion

One great way to get yourself out there is through networking. Face to face networking is all about exchanging ideas and information with the people you meet...
[rest of text]
```

### **AFTER** 
```
NETWORK
5-10 minutes: Discussion

One great way to get yourself out there is through networking, including connecting with industry- or mission-specific communities.

• Explore local and regional sustainability networks and events. 
  - Example: “KESK,” a local green enterprise in [location], hosts meetups for eco-minded entrepreneurs.
  - Look for sustainability-oriented events by NGOs, universities, and incubators (e.g., UNDP, local environmental groups).
• Face to face networking is all about exchanging ideas and information with the people you meet...
[Continue existing content about networking best practices]
```

**Why We Changed It:**  
- We added a **bullet** referencing **local sustainability entrepreneurs** (e.g., KESK) and emphasized that entrepreneurs should seek out **sustainability-oriented events** that match their mission.  
- This is a **small insertion** that makes the slide more **actionable** for eco-minded founders.

---

## 2. **Slide: HOLD AND ATTEND EVENTS (Before/After)**

### **BEFORE**
```
HOLD AND ATTEND EVENTS
5 minutes: Discussion

A great way to get your name out there is by holding events...
[rest of text]
```

### **AFTER**
```
HOLD AND ATTEND EVENTS
5 minutes: Discussion

A great way to get your name out there is by holding events (or attending sustainability-focused meetups if your brand aligns with social impact).

• Highlight local sustainability champions:
  - Invite founders like [Name], founder of KESK, to share insights on green entrepreneurship.
  - Consider partnering with local/regional “green networks” or social impact hubs.
• Ask: Why is holding events so important...?
[Continue existing content about the benefits of hosting/attending events]
```

**Why We Changed It:**  
- We **suggest** inviting or featuring **local sustainability founders** (e.g., KESK) as **guest speakers**, which encourages connection with **like-minded professionals**.  
- Aligns with the user feedback about **highlighting relevant sustainability entrepreneurs** in the region.

---

## 3. **Slide: CREATE A LINKEDIN (Before/After)**

### **BEFORE**
```
CREATE A LINKEDIN
1 hour and 10 minutes: Discussion + activity

5-10 minutes: Discussion
Finally, the last thing we will talk about as a way to build your personal brand is LinkedIn...
[rest of text]
```

### **AFTER**
```
CREATE A LINKEDIN
1 hour and 10 minutes: Discussion + activity

5-10 minutes: Discussion
Finally, the last thing we will talk about as a way to build your personal brand is LinkedIn. 
• If you’re focused on sustainability or social impact, connect with global networks like:
  - “Sustainability Professionals MENA” (group on LinkedIn)
  - “Green Startups Middle East”
  - “Youth4Climate Action” (global network that welcomes entrepreneurs)
[Continue existing text on LinkedIn tips and best practices]
```

**Why We Changed It:**  
- We **insert** examples of **LinkedIn groups** and networks that entrepreneurs can join to meet regional/global sustainability peers.  
- Keeps the original structure but adds **clear suggestions** relevant to sustainability-focused founders.

---

## 4. **Optional New Slide: SUSTAINABILITY & SOCIAL IMPACT NETWORKS**

If you want a **dedicated** slide on sustainability networks (instead of a brief mention within existing slides), add something like:

### **AFTER** (New Slide)
```
SUSTAINABILITY & SOCIAL IMPACT NETWORKS
5 minutes: Discussion

If your mission aligns with environmental or social impact goals, consider tapping into networks that share your values:
• Local networks
  - KESK (eco-friendly brand in [location])
  - [Add any local green coworking hubs or NGOs here]
• Regional networks
  - Arab Sustainability Association, MENA Climate Week
  - [Any relevant regional sustainability nonprofits or startup labs]
• Global networks
  - UN Global Compact
  - B Corps network
  - ClimateLaunchpad

Ask: Which of these networks or groups resonates with your mission? 
[Then segue into how to contact them, events they host, etc.]
```

**Why We Added It:**  
- Some participants may **specifically need** a curated list of **sustainability networks**.  
- Makes it easy for them to **research** and **reach out**.

---

## 5. **Implementation Tips**

1. **Keep It Simple**  
   - Do **short bullet points** referencing a **local founder** or **regional network**. Overloading slides with external info can distract from the main workshop goals.  
2. **Link to Next Steps**  
   - If you have time, give them a brief **research assignment**: “Explore one sustainability network from this list and see how you might benefit from joining.”  
3. **Ensure Accuracy**  
   - Double-check that these networks (local, regional, or global) are **active** and **accessible** for your audience.  

---

### Final Takeaway

By weaving **local sustainability references** (like **KESK**), **regional green networks**, and **global social impact groups** into your existing slides (and possibly adding one dedicated slide), you’ll:

- **Respond** directly to participant feedback about **highlighting sustainability entrepreneurs**.  
- **Provide** tangible **networking resources** for eco-focused founders.  
- **Enhance** the value and relevance of your **Personal Brand + Networking** session without significant extra content.

**Culling networks**

I'm gathering a list of sustainability and tech-related networks in the MENA region, such as "MENA Startups" Slack group, "Greentech" and "Sustainable Tech" Slack communities, and "Impact Hub" in various MENA countries.

Below is a curated list of **live links** and **active communities** you can explore for **sustainability-minded networking** (global, regional, and Slack/Discord-based). These complement or go beyond the 400+ Slack communities you already found. 

---

## **1. Slack Communities**  

1. **ClimateAction.tech**  
   - **URL**: [climateaction.tech Slack](https://climateaction.tech/join/)  
   - **Focus**: A global network of tech workers, entrepreneurs, and activists pushing forward climate solutions. Good if you’re building a tech or digital product around sustainability.

2. **Work on Climate**  
   - **URL**: [workonclimate.org/slack](https://workonclimate.org/slack)  
   - **Focus**: People transitioning into climate-related jobs or launching climate-focused ventures. Channels for job postings, founder advice, and climate resources.

3. **Purposeful Work**  
   - **URL**: [Purposeful Work Slack Invite](https://purposeful-work.slack.com/)  
   - **Focus**: Broadly about “work with purpose,” which includes many sustainability and impact-driven entrepreneurs. (You may need to request an invite via their site or social channels.)

4. **She Leads Climate** *(Women-Focused)*  
   - **URL**: [She Leads Slack Invitation Form](https://sheleadsclimate.org/)  
   - **Focus**: Women-led climate initiatives and green entrepreneurship. Offers regular meetups and channels for funding/collaboration.

---

## **2. Discord Communities**  

1. **Greenhouse: The Sustainability Hub**  
   - **URL**: [Greenhouse Discord Invite](https://discord.gg/5bbq5QvBVT)  
   - **Focus**: A friendly, broad-ranging server where members discuss eco-friendly technology, recycling initiatives, renewable energy, etc.

2. **Eco Warriors**  
   - **URL**: [Eco Warriors Discord Invite](https://discord.gg/NgtNtgZ)  
   - **Focus**: Grassroots environmental activism, with some entrepreneurs looking for solutions to local/regional environmental issues.

3. **Climatebase**  
   - **URL**: [climatebase.org](https://climatebase.org/)  
   - **Focus**: Not purely Discord-based, but has a large community that coordinates on Slack/Discord-like channels and is very open to connecting founders. Also posts climate jobs and events.

---

## **3. MENA/Regional Sustainability Networks**  

1. **MENA Climate Week**  
   - **URL**: [unfccc.int/MENA-CW-2023](https://unfccc.int/MENA-CW-2023)  
   - **Focus**: Annual event focusing on climate solutions in the Middle East & North Africa. Great place to meet local/regional sustainability entrepreneurs, NGOs, and government agencies.

2. **Arab Sustainability Association** *(Facebook + LinkedIn Groups)*  
   - **URL**:  
     - Facebook: [facebook.com/groups/ArabSustainabilityAssociation](https://www.facebook.com/groups/ArabSustainabilityAssociation/)  
     - LinkedIn: [linkedin.com/groups/9071206/](https://www.linkedin.com/groups/9071206/)  
   - **Focus**: Regional group sharing sustainability events, research, and announcements. Entrepreneurs frequently pitch collaborative projects.

3. **Iraq Innovation** *(Iraq-focused tech & entrepreneurship)*  
   - **URL**: [Iraq Innovation on Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/iraqinnovation/)  
   - **Focus**: Not exclusively sustainability, but a leading hub for local innovators. They periodically host or spotlight green entrepreneurship events or eco-startups (like KESK).

4. **Five One Labs** *(You may already know them!)*  
   - **URL**: [facebook.com/FiveOneLabs/](https://www.facebook.com/FiveOneLabs/)  
   - **Focus**: Startup incubator in the Kurdish Region of Iraq that sometimes organizes sustainability or social impact workshops, and fosters relevant networks.

---

## **4. Other Global Social Impact Networks**  

1. **UN Global Compact**  
   - **URL**: [unglobalcompact.org/participation](https://unglobalcompact.org/participation)  
   - **Focus**: Corporate sustainability initiative with local networks in some MENA countries. Companies/SMEs can join and meet other socially responsible businesses.

2. **Startup Refugees** *(Focus on refugees, but sustainability often featured)*  
   - **URL**: [startuprefugees.com](https://startuprefugees.com/)  
   - **Focus**: A global network supporting refugee entrepreneurs (including eco-focused). They may have programs or remote communities you can join.

3. **Impact Hub** *(Multiple MENA Locations)*  
   - **URL**: [impacthub.net/locations](https://impacthub.net/locations)  
   - **Focus**: Co-working + incubator space with a global network. Various Impact Hubs across the MENA region often have climate, sustainability, or circular economy programs.

---

## **5. WhatsApp & Other Suggestions**  
- **Local Incubator & University Groups**: Many run **WhatsApp** or **Telegram** channels where sustainability or social enterprise is discussed. Ask your local coworking spaces or entrepreneurial hubs.  
- **Creating Your Own Group**: If you’re not finding a robust local conversation, consider starting a WhatsApp or Slack channel for sustainability entrepreneurs in your city. Invite relevant local businesses, NGOs, and professionals.  

---

### **Final Tips for Joining & Engaging**

1. **Be Specific** – When you join a Slack/Discord server, introduce yourself with your focus (e.g., “Renewable energy in Northern Iraq”), so people can direct you to the right channels.  
2. **Offer & Ask** – Contribute resources or insights and politely ask for help or connections.  
3. **Stay Active** – Communities are most valuable when you regularly post updates, ask thoughtful questions, and attend virtual or in-person meetups.  
4. **Bridge Online to Offline** – If you find someone local or regionally close, invite them for coffee or a Zoom chat to solidify the relationship.

By exploring these **Slack**, **Discord**, and **regional MENA** networks—and possibly creating your own WhatsApp group—you’ll uncover many **like-minded sustainability entrepreneurs** and **potential partners**.

Tie to Slides: Reference Slide 5 (NETWORK) and the new Slides 8/9 (SUSTAINABILITY NETWORKS/ENTREPRENEURS) to frame it as a way to connect with figures like the KESK founder or UNDP/SPARK contacts.

Instead of making the activity explicitly about sustainability, we’ll **broaden it** to help participants **"Find Your People"**—whether they’re looking for co-founders, investors, mentors, customers, or collaborators. The **sustainability networks** can still be options for those interested, but they won’t be the main focus.

---

### **Updated Exercise: "Find Your People – The Networking Treasure Hunt"**
#### **Objective:**  
Help entrepreneurs **discover and connect** with people they need in their network—whether that’s a **mentor, investor, co-founder, customer, or someone in their industry**.  
Encourage **real introductions** and **immediate value** while keeping it **fun, fast, and interactive**.

#### **Duration:**  
15–20 minutes (fits in the "NETWORK" section)

#### **Materials Needed:**  
- Index cards or sticky notes (or digital equivalents if virtual)
- Whiteboard, Jamboard, or a collaborative Google Doc
- A **small reward** (e.g., LinkedIn badge, coffee voucher, startup swag)

---

### **Step-by-Step Process**
#### **1. Set the Stage (2 min)**
Facilitator opens with:  
_"No one builds their career or business alone—your network is one of your greatest assets. Today, we’re playing a game to help you ‘Find Your People’—the right connections who can help you move forward!"_

- **Explain the game:**  
  - Each participant will identify **who they need** in their network.  
  - They’ll also think about **who they know** that might help someone else.
  - The goal? **Make at least one useful connection before the session ends.**

---

#### **2. Preparation (3 min)**
Each participant gets **two index cards (or sticky notes):**  
- **Card 1: "I Need…"**  
  - Examples:  
    - "I need a **co-founder** with tech experience."  
    - "I need a **mentor** who has raised investment before."  
    - "I need **my first 10 customers**—who should I talk to?"  
    - "I need an intro to someone at **a local incubator or accelerator**."  

- **Card 2: "I Can Offer…"**  
  - Examples:  
    - "I know a great **lawyer** who helps startups with contracts."  
    - "I met an **investor** at an event last month—happy to introduce!"  
    - "I have **experience in branding**—I can give feedback on your startup’s story."

(Encourage **brief, specific, actionable** statements.)

---

#### **3. The Networking Hunt (10 min)**
- **Form small groups** (3–5 people).  
- **Each person shares their two cards.**  
  - Group members **listen actively** and **offer introductions** if they know someone relevant.  
  - If there’s a match, they **write down the person's name/contact** and commit to making an introduction.  
- **Add a "Treasure Points" system for fun:**  
  - 1 point: **A useful contact within the group.**  
  - 2 points: **Someone they can introduce outside the group (mentor, investor, accelerator contact, etc.).**  
  - 3 points: **A high-impact intro** (e.g., to an investor or potential co-founder).  

The **group with the most connections made "wins"**, but everyone benefits by leaving with valuable contacts.

---

#### **4. Wrap-Up (5 min)**
- **Each group shares 1–2 top connections that were made.**  
- **Encourage immediate follow-ups:**  
  - "Send a LinkedIn request or WhatsApp message right now!"  
- **Optional: Create a shared networking doc**  
  - Participants **drop their name, LinkedIn, and a short ‘what I need’/‘what I offer’ statement.**  
  - This can be used **after the session** to help build long-term relationships.

---

### **Why This Works**
✅ **More inclusive than a sustainability focus**—people can seek **any** type of connection they need.  
✅ **Gamifies networking**—making it **engaging** and **low-pressure** for introverts.  
✅ **Creates immediate value**—participants **walk away with real introductions.**  
✅ **Respects cultural norms**—by encouraging indirect, relationship-based intros.  

---

### **Small Slide Updates to Support This**
1. **Rename "NETWORK TREASURE HUNT" to "Find Your People – A Fast, Fun Networking Game"**  
   _(Make it inviting, no pressure!)_  

2. **Update the NETWORK slide (Slide 5)**  
   - Add:  
     - "Who do you need in your network right now?"  
     - "What’s one useful connection you can offer someone else?"  
     - "Use this session to make at least **one valuable connection!**"

3. **Encourage Actionable Follow-Ups**  
   - "Before you leave today, send a LinkedIn request or WhatsApp message to someone you connected with."

---

**Before:**

**Improved Version:**  
📌 **Fear Game: Making The Ask**  
🔹 **Step 1: Identify Someone**—Find an expert, entrepreneur, or professional you admire. It could be someone whose work aligns with your field or whose insights could help your business.  
🔹 **Step 2: Research**—Check their recent work, interviews, posts, or projects. Look for a connection or mutual interest.  
🔹 **Step 3: Craft Your Ask Using the "XYZ Formula":**  
*"Hi [Name], I came across your work in [specific area] and really appreciated [mention something specific]. I’m currently working on [your project] and looking for insights on [specific need]. Would you be open to a quick chat or message exchange? Also, I’d love to support your work by [mention something you can offer in return, even if it’s just sharing their content]."*  
🔹 **Step 4: Send It!**—No overthinking. The worst outcome? They don’t reply. The best? A valuable connection.

📌 **Follow-Up Best Practices**  
✔ **Timing Matters**: Follow up within 48 hours of meeting someone while the conversation is fresh.  
✔ **Be Specific**: Reference something you discussed.  
✔ **Offer Value**: Instead of just asking for help, share something useful (an article, event, or connection).  
✔ **Keep it Short & Actionable**: Don’t overcomplicate—1-2 sentences plus a clear next step.  

💬 **Example Follow-Up Message:**  
*"Hi [Name], great meeting you at [event]. I really enjoyed our conversation about [topic]. I came across this article and thought you might find it interesting. Looking forward to staying in touch!"*

### **1. Personal Alignment and Authenticity**

- **Empirical Evidence:** Research indicates that values-driven companies often outperform their peers. For instance, brands that prioritize their core values have been shown to perform 134% better on the stock market than others. citeturn0search2

- **Customer Loyalty and Trust:** Consumers are increasingly drawn to businesses that stand for something beyond profits. By clearly communicating and living your values, you attract like-minded customers who are more likely to remain loyal and advocate for your brand.

- **Emotional Connection:** Values resonate on an emotional level. By sharing your beliefs, you create deeper connections with your audience, fostering a sense of community and shared purpose.

- **Guiding Principles:** Values serve as a compass during challenging times, aiding in decision-making and maintaining course. This steadfastness contributes to business resilience and longevity.

Here are the updated slide texts you can copy and paste into your PowerPoint to reinforce the connection between values and business success:

---

### **Slide Title: Values Drive Business Success**
**Text:**
- Your values shape the way you build, operate, and grow your business.
- Entrepreneurs who align their businesses with their core values tend to:
  - Make better long-term decisions.
  - Build stronger relationships with customers, employees, and partners.
  - Differentiate themselves in competitive markets.
- Studies on ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) businesses show that companies with strong values:
  - Achieve **higher profitability** over time.
  - Are more **resilient** during economic downturns.
  - Attract more **loyal customers and employees**.
- Example: Steve Jobs’ obsession with **design, simplicity, and perfection** shaped Apple’s brand and product excellence.
- Question: **What values will define your business and set you apart?**

---

### **Slide Title: How Values Impact Business Performance**
**Text:**
- Companies that integrate strong values into their strategy consistently outperform competitors.
- **Case Studies:**
  - **Patagonia:** A brand that commits to sustainability and environmental activism. This authenticity builds customer loyalty and increases sales.
  - **Tesla:** Elon Musk’s vision for sustainable energy drives its innovation and market leadership.
  - **TOMS Shoes:** “One for One” giving model built a socially responsible brand that resonates with customers.
- Values are not just words; they are the DNA of a great company.
- **Action:** Define your business values. Ask yourself:
  - What will you **never compromise** on?
  - What do you want your **customers and employees** to feel when they engage with your brand?
  - How will your values guide **daily decisions and long-term growth**?

---

### **Slide Title: Your Values in Action**
**Text:**
1. **Integrity & Trust** → Leads to strong partnerships and repeat customers.
2. **Innovation & Creativity** → Helps differentiate and stay ahead of the competition.
3. **Sustainability & Responsibility** → Attracts investors and customers who care about impact.
4. **Community & Connection** → Builds lasting networks and support systems.

**Exercise:**  
Take 2 minutes to write down:
- **One personal value** that deeply matters to you.
- **One way that value will influence how you run your business.**

Then, share with the person next to you.

---

### **Slide Title: Business Success is Personal**
**Text:**
- Entrepreneurs **must live with their business choices** every day.
- When you align your company with your values:
  - You **avoid burnout** and stay motivated.
  - You attract **like-minded customers, employees, and investors**.
  - Your brand becomes **authentic and memorable**.
- **Final Thought:** Your values are not just “nice to have” – they are your **competitive advantage**.

FIVE ONE LABS
1 minute: Objectives

WHO DO YOU WANT TO BE?

15 minutes: Lecture + activity

When we talk about personal branding, it covers many of the same things as branding for your business. All of you know yourselves and have a vision for the future. You all add value and create something special in this world. While creating your personal brand, your job is to share your mission and communicate that value with others. Personal branding allows you to show what matters to YOU. As founders, your personal brand should be somewhat tied into your business brand. For example, maybe you personally care so much about the environment and you are on a mission to make the world a safer and more healthy place for people. You can work towards accomplishing that mission in so many ways (start a business that has a positive impact on the environment, start a blog tackling environmental issues, buy eco-friendly products, etc….) 
So before we get into ways that you can get yourself out there and start building a strong personal brand, you need to take some time to understand who you are and what you stand for.

5 minutes: Share
Go around the room and have a few people share their answers

Recap: The first step to crafting your personal brand is to lay a foundation that you can confidently and authentically build upon. The key principle here is authenticity. There is a misconception that building a personal brand means crafting a persona. But a persona, by definition, is a facade. It’s not a true reflection of who you are, and therefore, it’s inauthentic. Your personal brand should not be an inauthentic persona. You are the face of your business and you need to show up loud and proud about all of the amazing things that you are doing.

4

WHO DO YOU WANT TO BE?
Your beliefs become your thoughts,
your thoughts become your words,
your words become your actions,
your actions become your habits,
your habits become your values,
your values become your destiny.
5 minutes: Lecture 
Values are not just what we say—we express them through our actions, decisions, and habits. The more we consciously align our daily behaviors with our deeper beliefs, the more naturally our values shape our work and relationships
Your values stem from your beliefs. To make them tangible, start by reviewing your beliefs, shaping your thoughts, refining your words, reinforcing them through consistent actions, and embedding them into your habits. This process ensures that your values become a lived reality in your life, and through your life in your business.
5

YOUR PERSONAL BRAND
10-15 minutes: Discussion

Ask: What are ways that you can begin building this brand now? What can you do to get your name (and your business) out there? 
[[[Note: Remember, everything you do “speaks” - For example, if you don’t print your business cards in order to use less paper and use QR codes instead, this is an expression of your care for the environment.]]]
Potential answers:
Create a LinkedIn
Participate in events, panel discussions, and pitch competitions to build a better network and let other people know you and what you are trying to accomplish
Getting featured in the media, having a personal brand makes it easier for you to pitch and be found by the media (online publications, magazines, television, radio, podcasts, social media posts, articles, post by influencers, etc.). The media is in constant search of experts that can share their insights with their audience.
Create valuable content, and share it with others. Portray yourself as an expert in something. Create something valuable that others will want to share. As they share your brand, they also will be sharing your business that you represent. 
Start to introduce yourself to more people, follow up with them, and get in contact with each other to find ways to mutually support each other (begin networking!)
Brand recognition is one of the biggest obstacles for startups, and many never achieve it. Online marketing campaigns may not work if you do not make the effort to spread the word and show the world what you are capable of. To increase visibility. If you want to build a famous brand, there is often a person pushing that behind the scenes. You want to build awareness and show what you are doing  (which is running your business).

Ask: Why is it important that you actually work to implement these things and develop this brand? Who is involved and how does that impact your business?
Contacts: Having good contacts in today’s business world is so important. 
Partners: Having a strong professional brand shows that you are professional and have passion to be able to run your business. Show others that you are an expert in your field and that you are the right person to be running your business. This is a must have when approaching partners and potential collaborators. 
Customers: You may also find new customers for your business. With so many small businesses popping up, a brand that connects to a customer is much easier to trust faster. People will trust your business more if they know who is running it. It builds trust to see a face of someone doing good things behind the scenes and see all the experience they have. 
Investors: The best way to gain the attention of an investor is by speaking to him/her directly. Face to face conversations build trust and are the foundation of a future relationship. People can only invest in your business when they know you exist, and see that you are professional. 
You need to convince people around you that you are professional, and you have the grit, passion, and ethics to lead a business. People look at the individual's capability of carrying out a business idea. Increase the chance of investment. 
Good ideas are a dime a dozen. If the person isn’t there to implement the project and lead the organization, the good idea will fail. Investors tend to invest in the founders ability to bring an idea to life. Not the idea.
Team: When the founders stand for something and build a strong brand identity around a mission, this will trickle down to the business itself. Based on your values, you will create your policies and company culture. A strong founder is a part of a strong team which will make an even stronger company.

Recap: Your personal brand will be defined by your actions and how people view those actions. If you DON'T want to work to build a personal brand, you should realize that everything you do reflects on your business. If your reputation is as a cheat and liar, then it's going to be a poor reflection on your business. There is so much you can be doing right now to start developing a positive brand image and deliver your message to the world. 6

NETWORK
5-10 minutes: Discussion

One great way to get yourself out there is through networking. Face to face networking is all about exchanging ideas and information with the people you meet in order to create relationships that could help you grow your business. Already, you have had so many opportunities to network with people. Whether it is the judges that come for competitions, CEO Talks, business breakfasts, or people in the co-working space, Five One Labs holds events all the time, and you should take advantage of it! Make sure that you are taking the opportunity to talk to them and start that long-term relationship. 

If it was not mentioned on the previous slide, ask: How might your network be able to help you or your business?
Potential answers:
Find new customers, 
Find partners, 
Find suppliers
Provide information, advice or mentorship
Provide technical support,
Help find investment or other needed resources
Find team members or co-founders
Etc…

Ask: When you meet people face to face, what are some best practices? Note: Keep in mind that a lot of this is cultural and you should be able to recognize that one style doesn’t fit every situation. Be aware of who you are talking too so that you don’t come off too cocky and turn people off.
Potential answers:
Use stories to evoke emotions. You want to listen to them as well. Learn about what they are doing to try to find ways to collaborate in the future. Being a good listener is one of the best ways to be a good communicator.
Show actual evidence of what you are doing. Show them your website or product if it is available.
Smile when you speak. Look engaged and happy to be there.
Be memorable especially when you are meeting high profile people
Create a link between the two of you.
Have good body language.
Be confident! Even though it can be uncomfortable to talk to new people, just pretend you are confident for the time being. Confidence is key!
Be empathetic about the other person and their work .
Be open minded. You never know who you will meet and how they might be able to help you. 
Ask for their business card or a way to reach out again
Set up a reason why you might reach out again in the near future
Always be respectful
Ask: Networking can be hard and really intimidating especially for shy people. What are some best practices for networking when you are more introverted? 
Potential answers:
Network in groups
Look for other people standing alone. They might be a bit shy as well and easy to talk to
See if you can find out who is at the event ahead of time so you can mentally prepare yourself
Do your best to put yourself out there. Try not to stand in the corner alone by the snacks! Or you can use that as a really easy starting point for conversations.
Commit yourself to a goal before the event. 
Speak to 5 people 
Get 5 business cards. 
Find 1 person who could be a customer in the future
Etc… 
7

HOLD AND ATTEND EVENTS
5 minutes: Discussion

A great way to get your name out there is by holding events. 
Ask: Why is holding events so important to do (especially as an early stage startup)?  What kind of events can you start to hold right now?
Potential answers:
Get your name out there
Make partnerships and connections with different players in the ecosystem
Find potential customers
Find employees
You can have product testing events
You can have a launch party
You can have an event related to your mission and invite other organizations and people interested in your mission

Share an example of how holding events is really important.
The picture above shows the founder of Fix-It (an application that connects repair men to people who need something repaired in their home) meeting with a group of repair men. In this meeting, she gave an overview of the application and how it worked. She allowed them to test her product and give feedback on it. She was able to use this as an opportunity to sign repair men onto her platform which was essential for her product to work.

If you don’t hold your own events, you can at least attend events. If you want to network, go to as many events as you can. The more you talk to people about your mission and business, the more people will know about it. You can’t spend all your time at events, so be strategic about what you attend. It is a great idea to go to events that will have the people you are looking to meet. 
Ask: If you are interested in meeting potential customers, where might you go? 
Answer: Go to events/places where customers will be such as public events, universities, etc… (you have to know your customers to answer this)
Ask: If you are interested in meeting people who could partner or invest in your business, where might you go? 
Answer: Go to events/places where they are such as business seminars and workshops.
8

GET FEATURED IN MEDIA
5 minutes: Lecture + discussion

Getting featured in the media is a great way to build a strong reputation. These media outlets usually have a strong following and will give you a lot of visibility.
Give 1-2 examples of entrepreneurs who have been successful at this: 
Randi from our FFF was highlighted on Babylon FM. Randi is the founder of Shopyobrand. She is really active and tries to get visibility for her business.
Laylan from Dada was highlighted on NRT. From this press (among other things she was doing publically), she was able to build a buzz around her business. She even got invited to Baghdad to pitch and came in 3rd place. She made it to the next level and was able to go to Lebanon where she pitched again.

Ask: How could you get yourself featured in the media? 
Potential answers:
Network with people! The more you talk to people and put yourself out there, the more of a chance there will be of someone who might be in the industry or know someone who can help you get featured somewhere. 
At Five One Labs, we have journalists and reporters come for all different reasons (Demo Day, events, sometimes they just ask to do a story). If we see that you are active with your business and are making great progress, we will suggest your name to them. Alternatively, don’t be afraid to just approach these people and talk to them. They might offer to include you in a piece, but sometimes you might have to have to ask. 
If you are active and in the spotlight, people might reach out to you to learn more about what you are doing. 
Media outlets usually want to tell a good story so inspire others with your mission and vision.
Etc…
9

WORK WITH INFLUENCERS
5 minutes: Discussion

Influencers are usually trusted in the market because they are popular or have great knowledge and experience in a particular field. People really trust them and they have the ability to influence the purchasing of their audience. Even if they don’t influence purchases, they can influence their followers to also follow you or to spread the word about what you are doing. 
Ask: If you wanted to work with an influencer, how would you approach this?
Potential answers:
You can DM them
Use someone in your network to connect you
You can reach out to super famous people (you probably won’t get an answer), or you can reach out to smaller less known influencers
Etc…

In general, you can follow these 5 steps to find influencers to work with on social media: 
Monitor conversations online to see who is popular in the space
Identify influential people who you might be able to work with
Pinpoint what factors/values you share with these influencers so that you can approach them in a good way
Locate and recruit the influencers to work with you or partner on a project/campaign
Incentivize them to work with you. Sometimes you have to pay really popular influencers, but not always. If you are smart about who you approach and how you do it, you might be able to do this for free and benefit from sharing each other’s followers. You usually have to have a clearly aligned and mutually beneficial mission for this to work well. 

Ask: Who are people that you already know that you could potentially work with? Who are well known and influential people who are working towards a similar mission?
Maybe people have answers to this already, but maybe they don’t
Suggest that they begin to look into this and create a list of some people to partner with in this way.

5-10 minutes: Discussion
Finally, the last thing we will talk about as a way to build your personal brand is LinkedIn.
Ask: Who here has a LinkedIn? What do you use it for? How can you use LinkedIn to share your message and build your network?
Potential answers:
People who have (or have had) LinkedIn profiles should share. 
LinkedIn is a social media platform for professionals. 
It is a great platform to get visibility and put your face on the map.

You can search for a job or post job offerings here.
It is a platform to tell your story or the story of your business.

You are on a platform full of people who are interested in business, making partnerships, and more. 
You can find founders, students, employees, investors, subject matter experts, and more all in one place.
Conversation topics can be about a variety of industries, sectors, and locations.
You can learn about other businesses and opportunities.
Find supporters, advisors, or mentors.
You can stay up to date on trends and news in your industry.
It is a great platform for creating and building your network. You can add people that you meet from other networking events to your Linked in to help stay in touch. You can also use your LinkedIn to grow your network by posting content, engaging in conversations, and more. 
Potential partners and collaborators are there. If you are looking to make a connection to a particular business or looking for someone with a particular skill, you can easily search and find people on LinkedIn. If you have mutual friends, sometimes you can request an introduction to someone in the organization.  For instance, I have a project that I think UNHCR would be a great partner for, but I don’t know anyone from the organization, I can ask my friend who works there to connect me with one of her connections. Attract more clients by participating in events and sharing your experience with your network, building a personal brand that positions you as the go-to expert in a specific industry or niche helps you to attract more of your ideal clients. When you’re positioned as an expert, it’s also easier for people to refer clients to you.

“Entrepreneur in Residence” is showing that he is an entrepreneur and lives in Mosul

1 hour: Activity
Entrepreneurs will now work on their LinkedIn (either starting from scratch or updating their current profile)
Use the Personal Branding Checklist handout to guide you on what to do. 
A trainer will go around helping entrepreneurs get the right wording of their headlines and about me section. Make sure that it highlights their passion and it is also tied into their business. 
As entrepreneurs build their LinkedIn page, make sure they highlight the following points: 
Create your profile: Sign up and create your profile.
Make good connections: You can begin by adding your family, friends, past or current classmates, coworkers, judges, visitors from CEO Talks and other events to your network. [[Let's add an activity here to build our linkedin around a need our business has, leveraging people who know people directly in the program]]]
Highlight experience and expertise: Your professional bio is an important piece of personal information that will help you catch the interest of the viewer. It can be awkward writing about yourself, but it is important to highlight your past experience and successes. What skills have you acquired throughout your life? What training, credentials, certifications, or awards have you received? It is ok if your background doesn’t tie in perfectly with your business, but try to find links and similarities wherever you can (remember that a brand is consistent and telling a good story). 
Highlight your personality: What are some of your most important core values? What do you believe in? What do you stand for? What do you stand against? What industries and topics are you most interested in? What are you passionate about?

Trainer note: On a rare occasion, an entrepreneur might not want to do this. Encourage that they create one, but don’t force them. The entrepreneur can use the time to help other people in the cohort with this activity or work individually to come up with a personal branding plan.

Ask: After you begin meeting new people and growing your network face to face, what should you do?

Follow up! 
Reach out over email, phone, social media, or LinkedIn (depending on how your initial meeting went you might want to be more or less professional).

FEAR GAME
[[[3 minutes: Discussion

Asking can be scary. Especially if there’s someone you really respect or admire.
[[[improve the text here: Let’s play a fear game, find one person online in your field that you respect greatly, work to come up with a clear ask and follow this template: x y z a b c :For a short message they will be bound to ask. often you can ask what you can do for people first, especially if it shows you’ve really done your homework. ]]]]]]
13

ENGAGE MEANINGFULLY
5 minutes: Discussion

The follow up element of this is really important. You will never meet someone and then instantly they will provide you with all you need. You need to follow up with them and build a relationship with them over time. It would be good to learn about their needs so that you can help them too. 

Ask: What are ways that you can engage with the people you have met? How can you continue the conversation and build relationships?
Potential answers:
Email them to follow up on your conversation from when you met. Maybe give them resources based on what you talked about. Did they offer to provide you with something? If so, remind them. – During the follow up, make sure that you are polite and not demanding. Send an email and a follow up, but if there is no answer, back off and give the person some space. You shouldn’t assume that anything is guaranteed. 
Distinguish how professional the contact is. If they are more friendly, consider reaching out over Whatsapp or text message
Follow up on LinkedIn:
Post content: Post about the event you were at where you met the person. 
Tag people. This will encourage the people who were tagged to like, comment, and share which will help spread awareness about you and your business. 
Use the right hashtags to help you show up in the right conversations
Share pictures
Let people know what you are up to!

Participate in conversations: You can also contribute your knowledge and skills in conversations that are happening on the platform. You can easily participate in conversations on LinkedIn. Participating in conversations can allow you to share your perspective on relevant issues, things happening in your industry, and topics with others. You can like and comment on posts and articles on LinkedIn. You can create or join groups to connect and grow with members who share your interests, experiences, or aspirations.
14

ASK!
5 minutes: Discussion

Don’t forget, as you build your network, you are building opportunities for collaboration. You should feel comfortable reaching out to people in your network when you need something. Benefit from the relations you made and start asking and growing.  

Ask: What can you use your network for? How might they be able to help you?
Potential answers:
Provide expertise or mentorship
Support in a variety of areas or make a connection to someone else who can. Areas might include:
Customers
Partners
Supplier
Mentor
Investor
Etc…

Ask: Although a lot of this changes culture to culture, what are things you should do and not do when reaching out to your network for something?
Do:
Build a relationship with the person first. Spend time with them and learn about their needs.
Be polite
Offer something in return (time, support, resources, money, etc…)
Find things you have in common or common things that you are working on 
In emails, write a meaningful subject line and keep the message focused. 
Identify yourself clearly and remind the person of how you met and what you talked about.
Asking for advice is a good first step to start a conversation.
Proofread.

Don’t:
Don’t be too direct. Don’t just randomly email someone you are not close to and ask for something
Don’t expect them to just say “yes”. Be aware of the fact that the person might not be interested
Don’t be rude or too demanding
Don’t ask things from strangers
Don’t be too formal/informal. Distinguish between formal and informal situations and know when it is appropriate/inappropriate to ask for things. 

Recap: Once you build a relationship of mutual trust, then you can benefit from the relationship by asking for something. This can be anything from sharing their network, to advice, to resources. Be careful with your ask. Always be respectful and don’t demand anything.
